com.samysadi.acs.core.entity

Interface FailureProneEntity

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Cloneable, Entity, Notifier, Probed
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Host, NetworkDevice, NetworkInterface, ProcessingUnit, Storage, Switch, ThinClient, VirtualStorage
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    FailureProneEntityImpl, HostDefault, MemoryUnitImpl, NetworkDeviceDefault, NetworkInterfaceDefault, ProcessingUnitDefault, RamDefault, StorageDefault, SwitchDefault, ThinClientDefault, VirtualMemoryUnitDynamic, VirtualMemoryUnitElastic, VirtualMemoryUnitFixedSize, VirtualMemoryUnitImpl, VirtualRamDynamic, VirtualRamElastic, VirtualRamFixedSize, VirtualStorageDynamic, VirtualStorageElastic, VirtualStorageFixedSize

    public interface FailureProneEntity
extends Entity
    Defines a failure-prone entity. Such entities can be declared as failed.

    Note that even if a class implements this interface, that does not mean that it's failure state can be updated.
    Use supportsFailureStateUpdate() to see if this entity supports failure state update.

    When the failure state changes, a CoreNotificationCodes.FAILURE_STATE_CHANGED notification is thrown.

    Default failure state when instantiating a new object which implements this class is FailureProneEntity.FailureState.OK.

    Since:
    1.0

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        FailureProneEntity clone()
        Description copied from interface: Entity
        Creates a clone of this entity and sets its parent to null.

        This is a deep clone method which also clones children entities and sets their parents to the newly created clone.

        Implementations must ensure that the new clone will be independent from the current entity.

        Specified by:
        clone in interface Entity
        Specified by:
        clone in interface Notifier

      • supportsFailureStateUpdate

        boolean supportsFailureStateUpdate()
        Returns true if the FailureProneEntity.FailureState of this entity can be modified. Note that even if a entity implements the FailureProneEntity interface, it does not mean it supports state changing.
        Thus you have to check the return value of this method to ensure that you can use setFailureState(FailureState) safely.

        If this method returns false and you try to change the FailureProneEntity.FailureState of this entity you will get a UnsupportedOperationException.

        Returns:
        true if the FailureProneEntity.FailureState of this entity can be modified

      • getFailureState

        FailureProneEntity.FailureState getFailureState()
        Returns the FailureProneEntity.FailureState of this entity.
        Returns:
        the FailureProneEntity.FailureState of this entity

      • setFailureState

        void setFailureState(FailureProneEntity.FailureState state)
        Changes the state of this entity to the new given state.

        Additionally, if the state has changed then a CoreNotificationCodes.FAILURE_STATE_CHANGED notification is thrown.

        Parameters:
        state - the new FailureProneEntity.FailureState
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this entity does not support this operation
